newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania polls diverging over Iliescu.
newsitem.headline: Romania polls diverging over Iliescu.

text.p: For the first time in post-communist Romania, an opinion poll showed left-wing president Ion Iliescu trailing opponents ahead of next month's presidential and parliamentary elections.
A second poll published on Sunday showed Iliescu in front.

A survey conducted by the statistics chair of the Romanian Academy of Social Science for private broadcaster Antena 1 showed Iliescu coming third with 24.2 percent, to 31.6 percent for Emil Constantinescu of the opposition Democratic Convention and 28 for first post-communist prime minister Petre Roman.
A survey by independent pollster IMAS put Iliescu on top with 33 percent, in the race for the November 3 ballot, but showed his lead thinning from 36 percent in previous surveys.
The poll, commissioned by local private broadcaster PRO TV, gave Constantinescu 27 percent and Roman, 24.
Romania is the only east European country where leftwingers have been in office since the 1989 fall of communism.

Iliescu, who won two previous pols in 1990 and 1992, faces 15 challengers in the race for a new four-year term on November 3. The presidency will go to a run-off if no contender gets the 50 percent needed for an outright first-round win.
